message_1: Consider the elliptic curve E: y^2 = x^3 + 7x + 10 over the finite field F19. If P = (3, 1) and Q = (9, 10), what is P + Q?
message_2:
To compute P + Q on the elliptic curve E: y^2 = x^3 + 7x + 10 over the finite field F19, we will use the addition formulas for elliptic curves.

Since P ≠ Q, we will use the following formulas:

λ = (y2 - y1) * (x2 - x1)^(-1) mod 19
x3 = λ^2 - x1 - x2 mod 19
y3 = λ(x1 - x3) - y1 mod 19

Here, P = (x1, y1) = (3, 1) and Q = (x2, y2) = (9, 10).

First, we compute λ:

λ = (y2 - y1) * (x2 - x1)^(-1) mod 19
λ = (10 - 1) * (9 - 3)^(-1) mod 19
λ = 9 * 6^(-1) mod 19

To find the inverse of 6 modulo 19, we can use the extended Euclidean algorithm or simply try different numbers until we find the inverse. In this case, the inverse of 6 modulo 19 is 16, since 6 * 16 = 96 = 5 * 19 + 1.

So, λ = 9 * 16 mod 19 = 144 mod 19 = 11.

Now, we compute x3 and y3:

x3 = λ^2 - x1 - x2 mod 19
x3 = 11^2 - 3 - 9 mod 19
x3 = 121 - 3 - 9 mod 19
x3 = 109 mod 19
x3 = 4

y3 = λ(x1 - x3) - y1 mod 19
y3 = 11(3 - 4) - 1 mod 19
y3 = 11(-1) - 1 mod 19
y3 = -12 mod 19
y3 = 7

So, P + Q = (x3, y3) = (4, 7).
